definition: lit. you die, I live (idiom); irreconcilable adversaries/two parties cannot coexist
you (informal, as opposed to courteous 您[nin2])
to die/impassable/uncrossable/inflexible/rigid/extremely/damned
I/me/my
to live/alive/living/work/workmanship

sentences.chinese: 因此，競爭是你死我活的。

sentences.english: This is a life-and-death class struggle. It is dangerous to lose vigilance in such a struggle.
sentences.chinese: 這是你死我活的階級搏鬥，在這樣一場搏鬥中。

sentences.english: He and Ho Chi-Minh, out there alone, in a shoot-out.
sentences.chinese: 他和胡志明兩個人打的你死我活。

sentences.english: This leaves Washington facing a prolonged period of all-out partisan warfare.
sentences.chinese: 這讓華盛頓面臨着長期的你死我活的黨派之爭。

sentences.english: A life-and-death struggle is looming ahead.
sentences.chinese: 一場你死我活的鬥爭迫在眉睫。

sentences.english: You feel like the proverbial “rat race” is grinding you down.
sentences.chinese: 你感覺上就像要被那“你死我活的競爭”碾碎。

sentences.english: Is due to the knock-out competition starting on both sides fight to the bitter end.
sentences.chinese: 由於是淘汰賽，比賽開始，雙方就拼個你死我活。

sentences.english: The many brothers had a life-and-death fight in contending for the place of chieftain.
sentences.chinese: 他們兄弟幾個爲爭狼主之位鬥得你死我活。

sentences.english: "I would kill for a cup of wine, " muttered Tyrion.
sentences.chinese: “爲一杯紅酒我就能拼個你死我活，”提利昂喃喃。

sentences.english: After wrests from its shell it becomes involved in a life struggle with another insect.
sentences.chinese: 剛來到世上便與另一隻蟲子陷入一場你死我活的鬥爭。

sentences.english: Most people are sort of like all in a rat-race and scrabbling up together.
sentences.chinese: 很多人都像是在一個你死我活的競爭中，擁擠在一起。

definition: both sides suffer (idiom)/neither side wins
to meet on the battlefield (idiom)
lit. either the fish dies or the net splits/a life and death struggle (idiom)
to fight at close quarters/hand-to-hand
to fight to one's last gasp
see 撕破臉|撕破脸[si1 po4 lian3]
struggle/war
to be awfully (busy etc)
to vie against one another/to fight each other/mutual aggression
to massacre one another (idiom); internecine strife
lit. you fight, I snatch (idiom); to compete fiercely offering no quarter/fierce rivalry/tug-of-war
to fight openly and maneuver covertly (idiom)
two tigers fighting (idiom); fierce contest between evenly matched adversaries
lit. with swords drawn and bows bent (idiom); fig. a state of mutual hostility/at daggers drawn
the two cannot exist together (idiom); irreconcilable differences/incompatible standpoints
internal strife/power struggle/(of members of an organization) to fight each other
